entries.text: Have you ever wondered what is Yacc and Bison? Maybe Lex and Flex? Have you heard of Marpa? Do you know the job of a lexer and a parser? Do you know how to turn a grammar into a real language? Ron Savage explains all that.
entries.title: An Overview of Lexing and Parsing

entries.text: Joel Berger shows the power of Mojo::DOM that can use CSS3 seletors using a very simple and clear example.
entries.title: An example using Mojo::DOM for rewriting HTML

entries.text: Yanick Champoux extended his previous idea of testing the Dancer plugins, to test any set of Perl modules and to be extensible.
entries.title: Smoked Modules, Montreal-style

entries.text: Perlito allows compiling Perl to Javascript and running it in your browser. I think it can be very useful as an educational tool, or, if it had easy access to the DOM in the browser, you could write your front-end code in Perl.
entries.title: tie() in perlito5

entries.text: This is the first step in my attempt to (re)build the Perl distribution that will contain everything you will ever need to build Perl applications.
entries.title: Building DWIM Perl for Linux

entries.text: Tim Bunce finished just enough of the code to give a presentation at YAPC::Asia that you can watch after reading the description how this tool tries to help understanding the memory use of Perl applications.
entries.title: Introducing Devel::SizeMe - Visualizing Perl Memory Use

entries.text: Kevin Carillo from New Zealand is doing a research on Free/Open Source Software communities. He is asking us to complete his survey.
entries.title: Newcomer experience and contributor behavior in Perl and other FOSS communities - Survey

entries.text: It is probably only interesting to people who are writing applications where there is an actual interaction with users, but such application are also written in a modular way. So knowing how to make it easier to translate the text displayed by your application is a good thing.
entries.title: Localize Your Perl modules with Locale::TextDomain and Dist::Zilla

entries.text: The Perl Foundation offers grants between $500-$2000 for projects that need a little financial help. The dead-line to submit your proposal is 31 October 2012.
entries.title: 2012Q4 Call for Grant Proposals

entries.text: The report of Dave Mitchell contains a couple interesting issues with the regex engine of perl. For example you probably knew that using $` or $' will make your regexes slow. Did you also know that using these variables can make your regexes correct? It has been fixed now. (I'll let you guess which part was fixed.).
entries.title: Fixing Perl5 Core Bugs: Report for Month 31

entries.text: This is the report of Nicholas Clark.
entries.title: Improving Perl 5: Grant Report for Month 13

entries.text: Some interesting Perl 6 code examples by Solomon Foster (colomon). For example, operations on infinite ranges.
entries.title: Sums of Fourth Powers

entries.text: I think LinkedIN provides a great platform to find potential employees, employers, clients or service providers. For a long time it had a feature where you could recommend people by writing a few lines of, well, recommendation. Now they have a new feature that makes it much easier to endorese people. It is only a click away. brian d foy explains the new feature and recommends that you use it. I am not sure how to really encourage people to do that, but I do think it can be an important factor in finding good Perl developers. I'd also recommend to watch the linked presentation of Rachel Botsman.
entries.title: Endorsing Perl skills

entries.text: Dave Cross finished the second run of his Modern Perl training class in London. This time he charged a little money and more people turned up to his class than the previous time when the training was free.

header: I loved Cesky Krumlov and it was nice to be back in Prague after so many years. Prices are much higher than last time I visited, but the town is beautiful, and the clock is still working. We also had very good weather which made walking around very plesant. If you have the time, I'd recommend visiting Prague!
In the meantime, go read the articles:
